text:
It seems that for some yet unknown reason trailing /-character is not stripped or
ignored in the URL.

eg. URL http://server/directory/foo.html/bar will get you foo.html even if
foo.html is just an ordinary file and not a directory. Unfortunately I do not
know why this works with some files but with others. Usually one gets the error
message "404 not found and in the errorlog "File does not exist:
/ht_docs/foo.html/bar". But in some cases you get the foo.html file, and in
accesslog there is message similar to this one "GET
/other_directory/foo.html/bar HTTP/1.1" 200 1905 "-".

It does not matter which browser is used.
creator: liinu@uta.fi

text:
Sounds like a misconfiguration. Did you configure SSI for html files or PHP or
the like?
creator: nd@perlig.de
liinu@uta.fi
text:
The server in question does not have mod_php or mod_perl installed or in use.
SSI (server side includes) can only be used when files have x-bit set (x-bit
hack) or have .shtml suffix.

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Ok. What happens if you configure:

<Files *.html>
    SetHandler default-handler
</Files>

in a directory and then request a *.html file from this dir?

The problem is the SSI. If SSI is used eg. via XBitHack and URL is
http://server/directory/foo.html/bar and if foo.html file has x-bit set then
this is a valid URL and one gets the foo.html from server.

Why would the SSI cause Apache to more or less ignore the /bar part of the URL
in the example above?

Is the /bar part in the example URL somehow significant when SSI is used and is
there a reason why it should not be dropped from the URL and rewrite URL to
match the situation?
creator: liinu@uta.fi

text:
The /bar part is called path info and is supplied via the PATH_INFO environment
variable (not ignored). You may use mod_rewrite to forbid such URLs.
Apache 2 added a directive (AcceptPathInfo) to control it.

Thanks for using Apache.
creator: nd@perlig.de
liinu@uta.fi
text:
Thank you for your explanation and time. I have now a vague idea why the SSI
pages work like they do. I've now made a simple RewriteRule that hopefully
resolves this situation with our installation of Apache.
